facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 223 of 1964 was filed by special leave from the Judgment and order dated December 6, 1963 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 2273 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 223 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated December 6, 1963 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 2273 of 1963. K. Venkataranga Iyengar and R. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant.

facts.text: The appellant was elected as the President of Holenarsipur Municipality on September 11, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was elected as the President of Holenarsipur Municipality on September 11, 1962. At a special general meeting of the Municipal Council held on October 14, 1963, a resolution was passed in the following terms- This Council has numberconfidence in the Municipal President of Holenarsipur Municipality.

facts.text: A special general meeting of the Municipal Council was held on October 14, 1963, where a no-confidence resolution against the President was passed.

anchor.surface_text: At a special general meeting of the Municipal Council held on October 14, 1963, a resolution was passed in the following terms- This Council has numberconfidence in the Municipal President of Holenarsipur Municipality. On November 2, 1963 Mr. Narasimhiah, the President of the Council applied to the High Court of Mysore under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for the issue of an appropriate writ quashing the proceedings of the meeting which culminat- ed in the resolution of numberconfidence against him.

facts.text: Mr. Narasimhiah, the President, applied to the Mysore High Court under Article 226 on November 2, 1963, seeking a writ to quash the proceedings of the October 14, 1963 meeting.

anchor.surface_text: On November 2, 1963 Mr. Narasimhiah, the President of the Council applied to the High Court of Mysore under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for the issue of an appropriate writ quashing the proceedings of the meeting which culminat- ed in the resolution of numberconfidence against him. Prayer were made also for some companysequential reliefs.

facts.text: Holenarsipur Municipality has twenty Councillors.

anchor.surface_text: Holenarsipur Municipality has twenty Councillors. Thirteen out of the them sent a request to the President to companyvene a special general meeting to discuss a resolution expressing numberconfidence in him as President.

facts.text: Thirteen Councillors sent a request to the President to convene a special general meeting on September 25, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Thirteen out of the them sent a request to the President to companyvene a special general meeting to discuss a resolution expressing numberconfidence in him as President. This request was handed over to the President on 25th September 1963.

facts.text: The President did not take steps to convene the meeting after receiving the request.

anchor.surface_text: As however he did number take any steps for companyvening the meeting the Vice President acted in the matter-calling a meeting to discuss the resoulation to express numberconfidence in the President.

facts.text: The Vice-President issued a notice dated October 10, 1963, for a special general meeting on October 14, 1963, at 10 A.M.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice under the Vice-Presidents signature stating that it was proposed to hold a special general body meeting of the Municipality on the 14th October 1963 at 10 A.M. in the office premises and asking the members to be present in time was served on the Councillors.

facts.text: Notice was personally served on 15 Councillors on October 10, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On fifteen of the twenty Councillors the numberice was personally served on that very date, i.e., the 10th October.

facts.text: Notice was served on Councillor R. G. Vaidyanatha on October 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It was served on Councillor Mirza Mohammad Hussain on the 12th October and on the Councillor R. G. Vaidyanatha on the 11th October 1963.

facts.text: Notice was served on Councillor Mirza Mohammad Hussain on October 12, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It was served on Councillor Mirza Mohammad Hussain on the 12th October and on the Councillor R. G. Vaidyanatha on the 11th October 1963.

facts.text: Notice was served on three Councillors, including President Narasimhiah, Mr. Dasappa, and Mr. Sanniah, on October 13, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On three of the Councillors, viz., the President Narasimhiah, Mr. Dasappa and Mr. Sanniah, the numberice was served on the 13th October.

facts.text: Nineteen out of twenty Councillors were present at the meeting on October 14, 1963, including the President.

anchor.surface_text: When the meeting was held on October 14, 1963, nineteen of the twenty Councillors were present. The President, Mr. Narasimhiah was among them.

facts.text: The President claimed to preside but ultimately left the meeting; Vice-President Mr. Singri Gowda presided.

anchor.surface_text: He claimed to preside over the meeting. But, ultimately, he appears to have left the meeting. The meeting was then held under the presidentship of the Vice President Mr. Singri Gowda.

facts.text: Fifteen members voted in favor of the no-confidence motion against the President.

anchor.surface_text: The numberconfidence motion against the President was moved and was passed, fif- teen members having voted for it.

facts.text: Petitioner challenged the meeting on grounds including lack of three clear days' notice to all members.

anchor.surface_text: In challenging the legality of the proceedings of this meeting of 14th October and the validity of the resolution of numberconfidence passed there, the petitioner urged three principal grounds. The first is that the requisite three days numberice was number served on all the members and so the meeting was number validly held.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed the meeting was invalid because he was not allowed to preside, contravening s.24(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The second ground urged was that the meeting cannot be said to be properly held as he was number allowed to preside and the Vice-President presided. and thus s.24 1  a  of the Act was companytravened.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed the requisition did not comply with proviso to s.23(9) due to lack of 15 days' notice.

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, it was urged that the requisition for moving the resolution of numberconfidence did number companyply with the proviso to s.23 9  of the Act as 15 days numberice was number given of the intention to move the resolution.

facts.text: Mysore High Court rejected the contention on three days' notice following its decision in Writ Petition No. 2280 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On the question regarding the failure. to serve three days numberice of the meeting on all the Councillors, the High Court followed its own decision in another Writ Petition No. 2280 of 1963 and rejected the petitioners companytention.

facts.text: High Court held that the provision for three days' notice is directory, not mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment in Writ Petition No. 2280 of 1963 which was produced before us shows that the High Court took the view that as the numberices were sent on the 10th October they must he held to have been given on that date even though they were ,actually served on the 11th, 12th and 13th but, apart from that the High Court was of opinion that the provision about three days numberice was only directory and number mandatory and so the omission to give numberice would number affect the validity of the resolution.

facts.text: Supreme Court found that President left the meeting voluntarily before Vice-President presided.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the petitioners companytention that the meeting was number held in accordance with law as he was number allowed to preside, we are of opinion, on a companysideration of what material there is on the record, that it was after he left the meeting that the Vice President took the chair and thereafter the numberconfidence resolution was moved and passed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that 15 days' notice of intention to move no-confidence resolution is required only to the President, who received it on September 25, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the meeting was held on October 14 and the President received the numberice on the 25th September. There was thus more than 15 days numberice given to him.

facts.text: Supreme Court ruled that notice is given only when served, not when sent; five Councillors received less than three clear days' notice.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the numberice given to, five of the Councillors was of less than three clear days.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the three clear days' notice provision under s.27(3) is directory, not mandatory, per s.36 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the fact that some of the Councillors received less than three clear days numberice of the, meeting did number by itself make the Proceedings of the meeting or the resolution passed there invalid.

facts.text: Nineteen Councillors attended the meeting, and 15 voted for the no-confidence resolution; no prejudice from notice irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, nineteen of the twenty Councillors attended the meeting. Of these 19, 15 voted in favour of the resolution of numberconfidence against the appellant. There is thus absolutely numberreason for thinking that the proceedings of the meeting were prejudicially affected by the irregularity in the service of numberice.

anchor.surface_text: Is the requirement of three clear days numberice for the holding of a special general meeting as embodied in s. 27 3  of the Mysore Town Municipalities Act 1951, a mandatory provision? That is the main question which arises for decision in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to agree with the High Court that sending the numberice amounts to giving the numberice. Giving of anything as ordinarily understood in the English language is number companylete unless it has reached the hands of the person to whom it has to be given.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, nineteen of the twenty Councillors attended the meeting. Of these 19, 15 voted in favour of the resolution of numberconfidence against the appellant. There is thus absolutely numberreason for thinking that the proceedings

holdings.text: The meeting was held in accordance with law and s.24(1)(a) of the Act was not contravened as the President left the meeting voluntarily before the Vice-President took the chair.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the petitioners contention that the meeting was not held in accordance with law as he was not allowed to preside, we are of opinion, on a consideration of what material there is on the record, that it was after he left the meeting that the Vice President took the chair and thereafter the no confidence resolution was moved and passed. There can therefore be noquestion of any contravention of the requirement that the President shall preside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence on record shows President voluntarily left meeting before Vice-President presided; no forcible removal.

holdings.text: The proviso to s.23(9) was not contravened as fifteen days' notice of intention to move the no-confidence resolution is required only to the President, who received it more than 15 days prior to the meeting.

anchor.surface_text: There is. our opinion, nosubstance also in the contention that the proviso to s.23 9  was contravened. The proviso runs thus - Provided that nosuch resolution shall be moved unless notice of the resolution is signed by no less than one-third of the whole number of the Councillors and at least fifteen days notice has been given of the intention to move the resolution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: notice to be given to President; received on 25 Sep before 14 Oct meeting.

holdings.text: Sending the notice does not amount to giving the notice; notice is given only when served or tendered, so five Councillors received less than three clear days' notice.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to agree with the High Court that sending the notice amounts to giving the notice. Giving of anything as ordinarily understood in the English language is not complete unless it has reached the hands of the person to whom it has to be given. In the eye of law however giving is complete in many matters where it has been offered to a person but not accepted by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary meaning of 'giving' requires receipt or tender; no authority for dispatch equaling completion; disagrees with High Court.

holdings.text: The provision of three clear days' notice under s.27(3) is directory, not mandatory; failure to comply does not invalidate proceedings or resolution by itself.

anchor.surface_text: The question then is Is the provision of three clear days notice mandatory, ie., does the failure to give such notice make the proceedings of the meeting and the resolution pas- sed there invalid? The use of the word shall is not conclusive on the question. As in all other matters of statutory construction the decision of this question depends on the ascertainment of the legislatures intention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Shall' not conclusive; legislative intent from object, consequences, scheme (urgency proviso s.27(2), s.36); measure of reasonable time, not vitiating absent prejudice; analogy to Art.320(3)(c).

holdings.text: s.36 deems resolutions invalid only for irregularity in service of notice (including short notice) if proceedings prejudicially affected; applies to short notice under s.27(3).

anchor.surface_text: It is important to notice in this connection one of the pro- visions in s.36 of the Act. It is in these words - No resolution of a municipal council or any committee appointed under this Act shall be deemed invalid on account of any irregularity in the service of notice upon any councillor or member provided the proceedings of the municipal council or committee were not prejudicially affected by such irregularity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.36 covers irregularity in service/mode and omission of full period; legislature aware of English law; reinforces directory nature.

holdings.text: Proceedings not prejudicially affected by notice irregularity as 19/20 Councillors attended and 15 voted in favour of no-confidence resolution.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, nineteen of the twenty Councillors attended the meeting. Of these 19, 15 voted in favour of the resolution of no confidence against the appellant. There is thus absolutely noreason for thinking that the proceedings of the meeting were prejudicially affected by the irregularity in the service of notice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High attendance and majority vote show no prejudice from short notice.

holdings.text: Failure to give three clear days' notice to some Councillors did not affect validity of meeting or no-confidence resolution.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that the failure to give three clear days notice to some of the Councillors did not affect the validity of the meeting or the resolution of no confidence passed there against the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis: directory provision + s.36 + no prejudice = valid.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No. 2280 of 1963 which was produced before us shows that the High Court took the view that as the notices were sent on the 10th October they must he held to have been given on that date even though they were ,actually served on the 11th, 12th and 13th but, apart from that the High Court was of opinion that the provision about three days notice was only directory and number mandatory and so the omission to give numberice would number affect the validity of the resolution.

precedents.cited_proposition: notices sent on the 10th October must be held to have been given on that date even if served later, and provision about three days notice was only directory and not mandatory

precedents.citation: State of P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava 1 1958 S.C.R. 533

anchor.surface_text: In the State of P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava 1 where the question arose whether the provisions of Art. 320 3 c of the Constitution are mandatory which provides that the Union Public Service Commission or the State Public Service Commission shall be consulted on certain disciplinary matters , this Court laid stress on the fact that the proviso to the Article contemplates that the President or the Governor as the case may be make regulations specifying the matters in which either in general or in any particular class or in any particular circumstances, it shall number be necessary for the Public Service Commission to be consulted. Speaking for the Court Sinha J. observed - If the provisions of Art. 320 were of a mandatory character, the Constitution would number have left it to the discretion of the Head of the Excutive Government to undo those provisions by making regulations to the companytrary. 1 1958 S.C.R. 533

precedents.case_name: State of Punjab v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava
precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of Art. 320(3)(c) are not mandatory due to proviso allowing executive to make regulations dispensing with consultation
precedents.cited_holding: If the provisions of Art. 320 were of a mandatory character, the Constitution would number have left it to the discretion of the Head of the Excutive Government to undo those provisions by making regulations to the companytrary.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the petitioners contention that the meeting was not held in accordance with law as he was not allowed to preside, we are of opinion, on a consideration of what material there is on the record, that it was after he left the meeting that the Vice President took the chair and thereafter the no confidence resolution was moved and passed. There can therefore be noquestion of any contravention of the requirement that the President shall preside.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the failure to give three clear days numberice to some of the Councillors did number affect the validity of the meeting or the resolution of numberconfidence passed

edges.explanation: Holding h2 supports the interpretation of concept c6
Holding h2 that proviso not contravened directly addresses issue i3 on compliance with proviso to s.23(9)

anchor.surface_text: There is. our opinion, nosubstance also in the contention that the proviso to s.23 9  was contravened. The proviso runs thus - Provided that nosuch resolution shall be moved unless notice of the resolution is signed by no less than one-third of the whole number of the Councillors and at least fifteen days notice has been given of the intention to move the resolution.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the failure to give three clear days numberice to some of the Councillors did number affect the validity of the meeting or the resolution of numberconfidence passed

edges.explanation: Holding h3 constrains interpretation of 'giving notice' in s.27(3) concept c4 by defining it as served/tendered.

anchor.surface_text: o s.23 9  of the Act as 15 days numberice was number given of the intention to move the resolution. The High Court held that on the materials before i

edges.explanation: Holding h3 explicitly resolves issue i4 by ruling sending notice does not equal giving it, with overlapping spans.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to agree with the High Court that sending the notice amounts to giving the notice. Giving of anything as ordinarily understood in the English language is not complete unless it has reached the hands of the person to whom it has to be given. In the eye of law however giving is complete in many matters where it has been offered to a person but not accepted by him.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the failure to give three clear days numberice to some of the Councillors did number affect the validity of the meeting or the resolution of numberconfidence passed
igh Court rejected the companytention

edges.explanation: Holding rejects sent=given distinguishes precedent holding sent on 10th Oct given even if served later
General holding in h4 that provision is directory supports specific application in h7 that non-compliance did not invalidate
Holding h4 addresses i1 by holding s.27(3) provision is directory and non-mandatory, directly responding to whether it is mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: The question then is Is the provision of three clear days notice mandatory, ie., does the failure to give such notice make the proceedings of the meeting and the resolution pas- sed there invalid? The use of the word shall is not conclusive on the question. As in all other matters of statutory construction the decision of this question depends on the ascertainment of the legislatures intention.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the failure to give three clear days numberice to some of the Councillors did number affect the validity of the meeting or the resolution of numberconfidence passed

anchor.surface_text: It is important to notice in this connection one of the pro- visions in s.36 of the Act. It is in these words - No resolution of a municipal council or any committee appointed under this Act shall be deemed invalid on account of any irregularity in the service of notice upon any councillor or member provided the proceedings of the municipal council or committee were not prejudicially affected by such irregularity.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the failure to give three clear days numberice to some of the Councillors did number affect the validity of the meeting or the resolution of numberconfidence passed
numberice of the full period as required. It is interesting to numberice in this companynection that the English law as regards meetings of borough c

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, nineteen of the twenty Councillors attended the meeting. Of these 19, 15 voted in favour of the resolution of no confidence against the appellant. There is thus absolutely noreason for thinking that the proceedings of the meeting were prejudicially affected by the irregularity in the service of notice.

We have therefore come to the conclusion that the failure to give three clear days numberice to some of the Councillors did number affect the validity of the meeting or the resolution of numberconfidence passed

edges.explanation: Holding h7 addresses i1 by concluding failure under s.27(3) did not invalidate, implying non-mandatory nature.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that the failure to give three clear days notice to some of the Councillors did not affect the validity of the meeting or the resolution of no confidence passed there against the appellant.
